content.body: Clearly it was too much to hope for, that a decision on longdesc would let us move on from discussing it
Well, yeah.  I expected an email like that.
And now, of course, foliot claims he'll file a FO on it.
AryehGregor: The OOM is caused by trying to create a 2^32 - 1 square canvas.
AryehGregor: Every other browser seems to lazily create the canvas, we don't.
AryehGregor: If you add it to the document, I think every browser will hit OOM.
thought most browsers had upper limits on the size (like 10000^2 or something)
Maybe fail silently?
AryehGregor: (and seeming my computer doesn't have (2^32-1)^2 * 4 bytes of RAM, you're way off into impl-specific hardware limitations)
(you'd nee 64 EiB)
*need
hey
think data compression
roc: But you can't have the entire thing compressed, as then when you change a single pixel you'd have to uncompress the entire canvas, no?
(and there goes all semblance of performance)
depends on the scheme
So you vary scheme based upon canvas size?
in principle you could store an entire list of vector operations in the canvas and storage would be totally resolution independent
Gah, that's not what I mean at all
but I'm not all that serious
In this case it may just be down to how soon you allocate the pixel buffer
actually a fairly reasonable optimization that browsers could do is cap the internal canvas buffer size and just downscale as needed
that would be quite easy to implement and work pretty well in memory constrained situations

You don't need physical memory for the parts you're not drawing onto, you just need virtual address space, so you could wait for 66-bit architectures and then allocate the entire (2^32-1)^2 bitmap at once
So setting the IDL attribute doesn't cause us to allocate the buffer, but setting the content attribute does
That's totally untrue
Remembering to save makes a difference :)
We allocate when setting width/height, other browsers don't.
is there a public svn/git/hg repo where the spec docs are kept?
cheeser: http://svn.whatwg.org/webapps/
grazie
and the websocket spec is in there somewhere?
ah.  section 10.3 of complete.html
this is pretty different text than http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-socket-protocol/
where in CSS does it state that absolute positioning happens against the padding box origin of the containing block?
Is it the padding or the containing box you care about?
the padding box of the containing box
it states absolute positioning happens against the containing block; but the containing block consists of several boxes, margin box, border box, padding box, content box
it is not at all detailed on where the box is positioned against in most pieces of the text I read so far
As far as I can see it doesn't state anything on that level, it simply states that the containing box is the nearest positioned ancestor, rather than the direct parent
So you'd use the same box you would normally
What made you think it would be detailed?
Ms2ger, don't make me -- you ;p
Workshiva, that would be against the origin of the content box, but I think that is not what happens
make a better test
see http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/588
maybe this was already an open issue
checks that
Hmm
Looks like it uses the padding box, yeah
"Note: For absolutely positioned elements whose containing block is based on a block-level element, the percentage is calculated with respect to the width of the padding box of that element."
Part of the spec seems to be aware of it
"""The stack of open elements cannot have both a td and a th element in table scope at the same time, nor can it have neither when the insertion mode is "in cell"."""
That is wrong in the fragment case, no?
That is if you do tdElement.innerHTML then you will have neither <td> nor <th> in table scope
so it is defined people
bert bos to the recsue :)
http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/visudet.html#containing-block-details 4.2
(somewhat confusing imo, but that's what it is)
svn up
woops. :-/
changed offsetTop/offsetLeft per longstanding emails on the subject
apparently I cannot email outside of Opera until after midnight here (someone hit a cable close to Opera HQ o_O) but the change is comitted
I guess I should now change the terminology slightly to make it more confusing
e.g. instead of padding box of element it should be padding box of the first CSS layout box associated with element
hsivonen: (in the hope you pick this up when you get back from vacation), I just changed the html5lib test format slighly to allow non-HTML elements as the container in the innerHTML case
So if you do
#document-fragment
svg svg
that will be like setting innerHTML on a SVG element in the SVG namespace
except in theory there's no innerHTML on <svg:svg>
are we changing that?
(I'm in favor, fwiw)
Oh
Well the parser spec suggests it can happen
I didn't read the DOM APIs
It seems crazy not to change it
does it do the right thing?
seems nice
Well afaict it doesn't work in Fx at the moment
although I wonder what happens if you call it with a this object that happens to be a svg node
I mean in the draft
Oh
Well the parser seems to assume it can happen
I'm not sure it works, but it shouldn't obviously not work
if you see what I mean
notes that since it is a setter you can't really change the this object, which is sad
Oh well that makes my life boring
makes it or keeps it -- harhar
is also slightly bored
is looking at the mess that is scrollTop/scrollLeft and standards/quirks
and also <html> / <body>; it's a big party
Hmm, even messing around with __lookupSetter__ doesn't work
I wonder if there is a reason for that
I mean apart from implementation complexity
Oh well, I guess I should leave support for it in the test format so that it is there once I convince Hixie it's a good idea :)
ooh, I didn't quite mean it like that
I was just wondering whether the algorithms worked nicely for cases like innerHTML = "<rect/>"
not sure what specification should hook into it
maybe the SVG integration spec if that's going anywhere
but not having a spec hasn't stopped us before...
well if you doo innerHTML = "<svg><rect/>" it should all work fine
it's just you can't do SVGElement.innerHTML = "<rect/>"
Which is weird and inconsistent
I mean it shouldn't be any harder to get right than HTMLTableElement.innerHTML = "" or whatever
and I have a local copy of html5lib that supports it now so I guess I can test
Ah, it doesn't quite work at the moment
Because the root node is always in the HTML namespace
But one could put the root node in the namespace of the context node and take whatever steps needed to ensure that was never popped off teh stack of opene elements
and work from there
so much for accepting the decision of the almighty chairs
lol
Link?
http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/html-wg/20100812#l-167
So there's no mechanism for doing a long alternative write-up for a complex image apart from the half a dozen ones suggested many times?
Talk about putting the implementation before the use case
I don't really understand what a Formal Complaint is. I assume it is a Formal Objection
But I don't understand what is so bad about those
AIUI, a formal objection just means that it has to be recorded and disclosed to the director before publication.

there's nothing inherently bad about them, it just gives one final bit of oversight, and a way for objectors to overrule the editor and the chairs, in the event that the editor and chairs made a major mistake
Yes, but there seems to be a deeper dislike of them. Like if someone is just unhappy with a decision that is fine, but if they start using the word "Formal" people scramble to react
mostly because most objections are just a waste of time, and a way to continue keeping an issue open well after it should have been dismissed
AFAIK, it's rare for a formal objection to be acted upon, and it needs to be a very serious issue
but I think in the HTMLWG, too many people just start throwing around calls for formal objections too much when they don't get their way.
As far as I understand, you can only object to the way the decision was made, not the decision itself

I observe that if the chairs actually change their mind here, then we'll be obliged to go file formal objections and make up new arguments after the decision too, whenever anything doesn't go our way.  But I guess that's what you get from having too much hierarchy, everyone can always question decisions ad infinitum.
Workshiva, well, if the decision is insane enough, ipso facto it was made through an incorrect procedure, insofar as correct procedures should prohibit excessively insane ideas.
(moderately insane is okay for the web, needless to say)
AryehGregor: That doesn't sound like too much heirachy.
AryehGregor: I don't think you can axiomatically rule out excessively insane ideas
XHTML2 had a great run
In a very heirachical system the people at the top would just make a decision and everyone would have to live with it
Or kill them, I guess
A characteristic of hierarchy is that most decisions are made by lower people, who can be overruled by higher people.
So you can make lots of appeals.
In a flat hierarchy, there are no appeals.
Well, the gamble on FOs is that the higher up in the system you go, the less the decision-maker knows about the decision, so it's more likely he will agree with you even if you're wrong
AryehGregor: I guess that makes sense
The problem with too many appeals is it allows jurisdiction-shopping.  If it doesn't go your way, try again!  And again!  And again!
Well I assume that is what will happen here
The W3C isn't too bad in this respect, to be fair.  Only one of the appeal levels is insanely over-bureaucratic.
(namely, appeal to the chairs)
Formal Objections are pretty simple and hassle-free, plus I take it they tend to get a polite "Thank you for your concern, duly noted" response from TBL, so they're mostly a formality.
Since the decision went the way it did, it will be taken up with the a11y coordination people who will make it an inter-group issue so circumventing the HTMLWG decision making process
Although the danger of that is that sometimes they can randomly become not a formality and suddenly the Director actually has dictatorial power over everything at the W3C.
Well, I wonder if he even sees all the formal objections...
Although possibly the a11y people will accept that longdesc is at best a distraction from reall accessibility issues
*real

(I was told about a professor who was denied tenure at a university, and appealed to the interim president, which is usually just a formality.  The interim president was applying to be the full president, and part of that required a vote of tenured faculty.  Curiously, he gave the person tenure in this case.  Got her vote, huh?)
The a11y people could describe an extension spec to HTML5 in their own WG, I guess.
The great thing about standards is you have so many to choose from!
Yes, of course
That would circumvent the whole issue
In practice it makes no difference, since the only ones who seem to care about maintaining a validator are the WHATWG people.
And as far as the general public is concerned, validators are the final arbiters of standardness.
I guess the PR value of being part of the full spec is deemed worthwhile
Or maybe people are not making rational decisions
That is normal, so I guess likely in this case too
gsnedders, thanks for the diagnosis, fixed in the latest test version.
a hgroup cant contain a img element right ?
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/sections.html#the-hgroup-element
It can only contain h[123456].
that makes me sad
Can't you put the img inside a h123456?
Sure, although I will immediately point out that the word "contain" is not well-defined and therefore my answer is arguably accurate anyway.
Hmm, so MS has dropped support for distributed extensibility.  Hopefully that means it's dead.
(support as in advocacy in the WG, I mean, obviously)
I think I just accidentally selected most of the HTML5 spec and attempted to paste it into an e-mail.
reloads tab
reloads
cheeser: should be the exact same text -- the text file is generated from the html each time i change the html
Hixie: hrm.  ok.  things like the abstract and such don't appear to be in the html version.
no big deal, though.  i like the html formst.
format
cheeser: the abstract is in a title="" attribute
some of the boilerplate is brought in from other bits, but all the normative content is the same
some of the stuff, e.g. the definition of the "ASCII case-insensitive" is much earlier in the HTML version
s/the//
fair enough.  i've been looking for an html version for a while so this is nice.
having the svn history will be nice, too.
gotta find out what I need to change.  ;)

shows you the diffs

wants a decent blogging platform

gsnedders, what would be your requirements… that would lead to a web apps Choose Your blogging platform. You would select your features. If some platforms would meet all your requirements, you would get the list of them. If none, the message would be "ROLL YOUR OWN"
karlushi: Doing that manually leads to "ROLL YOUR OWN". Then I remember I'm lazy.
What do you have against Wordpress?
I'm vaguely thinking I want a blog too.

AryehGregor: The community around it died long ago. It's now little more than a for-profit company (i.e., Automattic) paying for everything and controlling the entire project, and as far as I can tell it's even harder now than when there was a community around it (when it was hard enough) to get code in
Interesting.
AryehGregor: Also: it tries to output XHTML, no way to change that to HTML. No way to guarantee it is well-formed…
What are other choices you've considered?
"Roll your own" leads to an annoying lack of features.
AryehGregor: Hint: there's a reason why I ended up fairly heavily involved in Habari shortly after that went public (which is half the people the WP community used to be)
Like no e-mail notification for comments, if comments are supported at all . . .
has never heard of Habari
(Basically fed up with the direction of the project, started a new blogging platform)
gsnedders: I don't think it ends up being significantly XHTML (that is, non-html-compatible), though.  My old company's blog is run on Wordpress, and it works great.
If it were non-HTML-compatible, it wouldn't work.
So, yeah.
Right. But even then, it's still trivial to get the things that are XML (like feeds) to not be well-formed
Ah, yeah, probably.
(Habari doesn't have that problem)
http://www.blogkazani.com/yazi/interview-with-habari-developers has a fair bit about Habari's beginnings
(it's also really old)
(that post, not Habari)
(disclaimer: I am on the PMC of Habari)
(Most of my issues with it are more down to things that PHP makes hard, like Unicode, more than anything really related to the impl)
(And my few issues with the impl are things where you'd need to rewrite large parts of it to fix)
is rolling his own but has very few features requirements
karlushi: Yeah, I don't exactly have many either.

Rik`, it is :) but that it is not my own ;) and sincerely I do not like it at all :)
